abstract.text: A view subclass that renders a SpriteKit scene.

inlineContent.text: You present a scene by calling the view’s

method. When a scene is presented by the view, it alternates between running its simulation (which animates the content) and rendering the content for display. You can pause the scene by setting the view’s

abstract.text: A visual WatchKit element that displays a SpriteKit scene.
A true value.
Add high-performance 2D content with smooth animations to your app, or create a game with a high-level set of 2D game-based tools.
An object that renders a scene into a custom Metal rendering pipeline and drives the scene update cycle.
An object used to perform an animated transition to a new scene.
A view subclass that renders a SpriteKit scene.
A Boolean property that indicates whether the view is rendered using transparency.
Converts a point from scene coordinates to view coordinates.
Converts a point from view coordinates to scene coordinates.
A delegate that allows dynamic control of the view’s render rate.
The number of frames that must pass before the scene is called to update its contents.
A Boolean value that indicates whether parent-child and sibling relationships affect the rendering order of nodes in the scene.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the content is rendered asynchronously.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view’s scene animations are paused.
The animation frame rate that the view uses to render its scene.
Presents a scene.
Transitions from the current scene to a new scene.
The scene currently presented by this view.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view automatically culls non-visible nodes from the rendering tree.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view displays the number of drawing passes it needed to render the view.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view displays a frame rate indicator.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view displays information about physics fields in the scene.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view displays an overlay that shows physics bodies that are visible in the scene.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view displays physics-related debugging information.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view displays the number of rectangles used to render the scene.
Renders the contents of a node tree and returns the rendered image as a texture.
Renders a portion of a node’s contents and returns the rendered image as a texture.
Methods to take custom control over the view’s render rate.
Compare the different ways to display a SpriteKit scene.
Render a portion of the node tree into a new texture.

abstract.text: Switch to the legacy renderer temporarily for debugging purposes.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
